title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
A thesis is an arguable statement about an interpretation of a text.

A thesis may be one or more sentences anywhere in the response.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully conveys that line of reasoning.

At this point in the course, students should have a good understanding of skills related to literary analysis. As such, the thesis should be well developed, earning a point as one would on the summative (May) AP Exam.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a defensible thesis that presents an interpretation and may establish a line of reasoning.

title: Part B: Evidence and Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the last point in this row.

Commentary connects the evidence and reasoning to the thesis.

This poem employs a number of contrasts. Although the concept of contrasts in texts was introduced in earlier units, it is revisited in Unit 6 in a more sophisticated way: Unit 6 focuses on helping students understand how contrasts can introduce nuance, ambiguity, or contradiction that makes texts more complex. This preparation should be useful to students as they approach this passage and task. By this point in the course, students should be gaining familiarity with the skills required for developing commentary that connects evidence and reasoning. However, they are not expected to be entirely consistent in their explanations of the relationships between evidence and thesis; thus, students may only earn up to 3 points in this row for this unit. In some cases, student responses may exceed the criteria for these 3 points on this formative assessment. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row in later units and on the summative AP Exam.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
The response meets one of the following criteria:

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides commentary; however, it repeats, oversimplifies, or misinterprets the cited information or evidence.

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides commentary that explains the relationship between evidence and the thesis; however, commentary is uneven, limited, or incomplete.

title: Part C:  Sophistication
stimulusHtml:
Demonstrates a sophistication of thought or develops a complex literary argument by:

1. Explaining the significance or relevance of an interpretation within a broader context.

2. Discussing alternative interpretations of a text.

3. Recognizing and accounting for contradictions and complexities within the text.

4. Using relevant analogies to help an audience better understand an interpretation.

5. Utilizing a prose style that is especially vivid, persuasive, convincing, or appropriate to the studentâ€™s argument.

As students experiment and take risks in their writing, you might consider awarding a point for sophistication even if their attempts are not entirely successful; at this point in the course they should have some familiarity with these elements but may still need practice to employ them effectively.
descriptions: Response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
Response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
